Award.AwardTitle: Cellular Crowding Effects of Biomolecular Stability and Dynamics

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
Cellular environments consist of dense, heterogeneous solutions of biomolecules that differ significantly from the dilute, homogeneous conditions typically considered in structural biology. A consideration of the resulting crowding effects is essential to fully understand biomolecular function in cellular environments. Simulations with realistic models of cellular proteins and nucleic acids are used to examine the physicochemical effects of crowding. The main goal is to better understand the role of intermolecular interactions and altered solvent properties on biomolecular stability upon crowding. The simulations carried out involve models ranging from fully atomistic explicit solvent representations to multi-scale models where solvent and/or crowders are modeled in a simplified fashion. The results from the simulations are essential for developing effective models of cellular environments that are unavailable at the time but urgently needed for large-scale simulations of cellular dynamics.

Broader Impacts:
The broader impact to society will be a more comprehensive understanding of cellular processes from a physical perspective. More specifically, the research aims to connect the detailed molecular-level understanding of biology to processes occurring on cellular and systems levels. Ultimately, such insight will allow the development of detailed in silico cellular models based on physical principles that can be queried to understand complex biological processes. A number of more specific broader impacts will be catalyzed by the research proposed here: Interdisciplinary training of students at the interface of physical, biological, and computational sciences, both graduate students and teams of undergraduate students from physical and biological sciences; promotion of the involvement of women; focused efforts to recruit undergraduates from underrepresented minorities through the IDEAS program at MSU; enhancement of widely used modeling software; promotion of an international collaboration with RIKEN in Japan including short-term research visits abroad for students involved in the project; and broad dissemination of research results through traditional channels as well as public outreach through public presentations to lay audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most of biology takes place inside densely crowded cells yet the effects of such an environment on the essential biological molecules such as proteins and DNA have remained unclear. This project focused on building computational models of cellular environments at high, atomistic resolution and based on physical principles followed by simulation to study the dynamic behavior of biomolecules in such an environment.

A major accomplishment has been the data-driven construction and simulation of a model of the interior of a cell in full atomistic detail. This model has demonstrated how frequent interactions between biomolecules can destabilize functionally relevant structures and affect the time scales on which molecules move around. Further simulation studies have suggested that the degree to which proteins interact transiently with each other is directly related to how fast they can move under crowded conditions.

A second major accomplishment has been the construction of a high-resolution model of genomic DNA for the bacterium Caulobacter crescentus based on experimental data that allows a direct mapping of the genome onto the three-dimensional structure of the DNA. Such a model is the necessary starting point for a complete understanding of how proteins and DNA interact inside the cell.

As the scientific questions have pushed the envelope of knowledge, computational methodology also had to be advanced to be able to carry out this project. A specific outcome is a better description of intermolecular interactions that results in closer agreement between simulations and experiment and the need to simulate very large molecular systems has led to improvements in simulation software.

The project has involved a number of postdoctoral scientists, graduate students, and undergraduate students as well as a collaboration with a Japanese group at RIKEN offering rich, inter-disciplinary training for future scientists. Particular emphasis was placed on the involvement of women and underrepresented minorities with the goal of increasing their participation in the sciences and related disciplines.


Last Modified: 08/28/2018
Modified by: Michael Feig
